articles.title: Course presentation: statistical models link data to theory
articles.contents:
Slides





Further reading
Quantitative Reasoning in Ecology: Chapter 1 in Schneider,
D. 2009. Quantitative Ecology: Measurement, Models, and
Scaling. New York, Academic Press, 2nd Ed.
(Nice synthesis of
statistical analyses in the context of quantitative reasoning. It has
also many important highlights on quantities and measurements)
Alternative views of scientific method and of modelling:
Chapter 2 in Hilborn, R & Mangel, M. 1997. The Ecological
Detective - Confronting Models with Data. Princeton, Princeton
University Press.
(The whole book is a true classic on
the use of statistical models in ecology. This chapter has a quick
epistemological review and highlights the key distinction between
models and hypothesis. It also brings a typology of models, and
the concept of model complexity.)

McElreath, R., 2018. Statistical Rethinking: A Bayesian Course with Examples in R and Stan, 2nd ed. CRC Press.

Further reading

Ecological Models and Data in R Princeton: Princeton University
Press.
Hobbs, N.T. & Hilborn, R. 2006. Alternatives to statistical
hypothesis testing in ecology: A guide to self-teaching. Ecological
Applications: 16(1): 5-19.
The Concept of Likelihood , chapter 2 in: Edwards, A.W.F., 1992
Likelihood. Baltimore: John Hopkins University Press.
Introduction, and Information and likelihood theory. chapters 1-2
in Burnham, K. P., & Anderson, D. R. (2002). Model Selection and
Multimodel Inference: A Practical-Theoretic Approach, 2nd ed. New
York, Springer-Verlag.

articles.title: Statistical models: linking data to theory
articles.description: Serrapilheira Training Program in Quantitative Biology and Ecology - 2024
articles.contents:
Welcome to the Statistical Inference module of the
Serrapilheira Training Program in Quantitative Biology and
Ecology 2024. Statistical models are a useful tool to bridge theory
and data. Why do ecologists fit statistical models? There are three
main reasons: explore data, make inferences, and derive predictions.
Check here the 2023 course website
Goal
Our general goal is to provide appropriate conceptual foundations on
statistical thinking in ecology. We will teach you basic tools needed to connect
theory and hypothesis to data and show you additional paths you can
take to further explore more advanced topics. There are two main steps
in this endeavor: (i) the construction and fit of statistical models;
and (ii) the inferences that can be made with and about the models.
Instructors
Sara Mortara re.green, ¡liibre!
Diogo Melo, Princeton University
Paulo Inácio Prado, Universidade de São Paulo
Instuctors from previous courses
Andrea Sánchez-Tapia, Universidade Federal do ABC, ¡liibre!
Paula Lemos-Costa, The University of Chicago
Preparing for the course
Before the course starts, follow these
instructions to install R  and
the necessary R packages in your computer, and also to recap the
basics on R we’ll need to start.
